review_blob: Poured from bottle into Crate and Barrel craft glass. Pours a clear copper with a slightly off white head that settled to a quarter inch layer that stayed all the way down. Plenty of lacing. Lots of champagne-like bubbles. Aroma is hoppy, fruity. Definitely get the apricots when sipped. Was worried the apricot would be overpowering but its subtle. Much more bitter than I expected, but not at all unpleasant. Full somewhat sticky mouthfeel. Plenty of soft carbonation. Very nice!

Poured from bomber into tulip glass. Deep amber color. Aroma is pine, hops, alcohol, citrus. Taste is fruity hoppy bitterness. Resin, pine, hops, apricots, butterscotch. Nice body, sticky creamy texture. Lively carbonation. LONG lingering bitter finish. My first BrewDog offering. Sorry to see it end!

Poured from bomber into shaker. Poured a beautiful amber with a dense foamy head. Huge amounts of lace. Aroma was grass, floral, fruit and lots of hops. Taste was juicy with plenty of hop bitterness. I didnt get the blueberry as others did but there is a lot of fruity undertones, citrus and peach. Nice full slick creamy mouthfeel. Perfectly carbonated. Fairly quick bitter finish. I really enjoyed this, looking forward to others in the series.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Single Hop IPA - Yakima #291

review_blob: Poured from growler into tulip glass. Dark thick pour with one finger of dense tan head. Small rising bubbles reminds me of Guinness. Aroma is roasty malt, dark chocolate, coffee, nuts, raisin, a hint of smoke. Taste is very much the same. Full mouthfeel, thick, creamy, somewhat sticky. A nice bit of carbonation here. Nice long bitter finish. I think of porters as a bit sweeter than this. If I didnt know what it was, I would guess it to be a stout. Extremely good overall though!

Poured from bottle into tulip glass. Pours a beautiful dark with a big creamy tan head. Aroma is malt, roasty, toast, coffee, nutty, earthy. Taste is malt, very smooth and creamy body, a bit more watery that I expected but maybe thats because it looks and smells so much like a stout. I dont get a lot of hop in either the aroma or the taste. Nice carbonation. Not a lot of finish but I kept going back for another sip. My first Anchor sampling...very nice!

Picked up a 6 pack of this at Kroger. Was a new feature beer. VERY disappointed in the porter, so I was a bit nervous about this. Thankfully, this was a much better offering.
Poured from bottle into glass. Color is a nice amber orange with a fluffy head that quickly faded to a thin layer/ring. Aroma is citrus, floral and hops. Taste is hoppy with citrus, apricot, peach. Medium body, a bit thin but somewhat creamy. Good lively carbonation. Nice long hoppy finish. Not bad, have had better, have certainly had worse.
beer_name: Deschutes Red Chair Northwest Pale Ale

review_blob: UPDATED: JAN 26, 2014

Poured from bottle into Crate and Barrel craft beer glass. Poured a light amber with a big frothy pure white head. Aroma is hops and more hops. Taste is bitter juicy hoppy with plenty of grapefruit. Be careful because the almost 9% ABV is very well disguised within all that hoppy goodness. A very tasty DIPA!

Poured from bottle into imperial pint glass. Pour was dark, thick, oily. Quite a bit of dense tan foam that faded to a thin layer. Lots of lacing and sheeting as consumed.
After pouring let it warm in glass for a bit. Aroma is bread, coffee, chocolate, walnuts and bourbon. Lots of sweetness but balanced by malty bitterness. Lots of coffee flavor here along with dark chocolate. The nearly 11% ABV is VERY well hidden. Would never guess this is an imperial stout. 
Mouthfeel is full, thick, creamy, sticky. Nice amount of soft carbonation. Finish is long and bitter with the smallest bit of warming.
A nice stout on a cold Christmas Eve.
beer_name: Laughing Dog The Dogfather Imperial Stout - Bourbon Barrel

review_blob:
Just recently available in Ohio in 22 oz bottles. Poured into glass. Beautiful clear yellow/amber with a full white head. Lots of rising champagne-like tiny bubbles all the way to the end of the glass. Plenty of lacing as well.
Aroma is pine, grapefruit, hops. All somewhat faint. Not as much aroma as I expected. Taste is average IPA, pleasantly bitter, hoppy, with grapefruit. Not nearly as juicy as some IPAs Ive had. Mouthfeel is somewhat light, slightly sticky, creamy texture with a lot of lively carbonation. Bitter and dry finish. 
Not bad for a $2.99 bottle, but nothing really memorable.

Recently available in Ohio. $2.99 for a 22 ounce bomber. Not sure if this is an introductory price or (hopefully) permanent.
Poured into glass. Color is nothing special, clear pale yellow orange.
Aroma is yeasty, cheese, banana, herbs.
Taste is nowhere as complex as anything by Ommegang, Weyerbacher or Chimay but not bad at all. Medium body, somewhat sticky creamy texture. Lively carbonation (nice in this style). Finish is long and yeasty. An above average offering for the price but if the price jumps up I would consider buying something else.

Poured from bottle into shaker glass. Deep clear red copper with a small head that faded to a thin layer of bubbles. Quite a bit of lacing. Aroma is malt, roasty, clove, cinnamon, orange. All those same flavors when tasted. Medium body, somewhat creamy texture, even if a bit thin and watery. Plenty of carbonation. Lingering spicy bitter finish.
To date probably the best Christmas/Winter ale Ive had! I expected lots of spice/flavor and this definitely delivered.
UPDATED: DEC 16, 2013

Poured from bottle into shaker glass. Dark brown/black with small tan head. Faded to thin layer that stayed all the way down and left lots of lace. Aroma of malt, bread, coffee, barnyard, cheese, vanilla. Complex tastes. Lots of malt, yeast, bread. Sweet but nicely balanced. Mouthfeel is pretty thin and watery, probably my least favorite element of this beer. Im not sure I would say the carbonation is "champagne-like" but quite lively. Finish is long and yeasty. A very nice beer overall.

Poured from 22 ounce bottle into imperial pint glass.  Very dark pour with a thin tan head that faded to a ring.  Quite a bit of lacing as consumed.
Aroma is amazing!  Just what you would expect from a gingerbread stout.  Lots of roasted malt, and all the gingerbread aromas are there too.  Ginger, clove, cinnamon, nutmeg.  All there in the taste too but pleasantly so.  Not at all overpowering or cloying.  Mouthfeel is full and thick and rich and sticky.  Finish is long and spicy.  9% ABV is not at all noticeable.  Typical carbonation for a stout...very soft.  Very smooth and easy drinking.  One tip...let it warm up a bit before drinking to really develop the aromas and flavors.
This is so much better than any of the pumpkin beers I tried last month!

Poured from bottle into tulip glass. 
Another great beer from what is becoming one of my favorite breweries. And I love that its Ohio made!
Aroma is malt, coffee, bread, yeast, alcohol. Pours a dark mahogany with a pretty good tan head. Lots of lacing. Tastes of coffee, molasses, malt, nuts, a hint of soy. Really good balance of sweet and bitter. Full and rich mouthfeel, creamy sticky texture. A nice amount of carbonation. Fairly long coffee finish. Ive been wanting to try this for awhile and definitely lived up to my hopes!

Poured from bottle into tulip glass. Thick dark pour with just a touch of dark tan foam that quickly faded to a ring. Lovely rush of bubbles at the end of the pour.
Aroma is coffee, toast, licorice, cocoa and alcohol. Definite coffee taste, with lots of malt and some licorice, raisin, just a touch of soy. Nice full creamy texture. Very easy to drink, and would NEVER know this is nearly 10% ABV. No harshness or even the usual alcohol warming with this.
I have a feeling this would have benefited by coming closer to room temperature before drinking, but I was impatient to try it! A wonderful stout, and Ohio made!
beer_name: Thirsty Dog Siberian Night Imperial Stout

review_blob: Poured from bottle into shaker glass. Gorgeous copper amber color with a nice head. Deceptively strong. Hides the 10% ABV very well. Has some nice warmth but otherwise nothing harsh about this...so very smooth and mellow. Nice hop presence, with a good malt base. Reminds me of an east coast IPA but with more...goodness. Was lucky enough to spend some time in Maine recently and brought home quite a bit of Allagash. Just wish I had more!

Poured from bomber into tulip. Had really mixed feelings about this one.
Great aroma...smelled like a pumpkin pie. First sip...same reaction. This tastes like a warm boozy pumpkin pie. Was nice for a bit...then got to be a bit overpowering...then better...then over the top.
I would definitely have this again but a bottle for myself is just too much.

Poured from bottle into tulip glass. VERY dark pour with a single finger of tan head that disappeared into a ring. Lots of lacing and sticky residue as consumed.
Aroma is malt, coffee, toast, leather, alcohol, soy sauce, raisin, vanilla, smoke.
Big taste...wow. Coffee, cocoa, licorice, raisin, boozy, molasses...very complex and deep flavors here.
Big full body, creamy thick sticky texture. Soft carbonation and a lingering bittersweet finish.
I may have to get another 4 pack of this and let it cellar...but really good as is!

Got this on the recommendation of one of the salespeople at The Andersons in Columbus Ohio.
Poured from can (yes can) into tulip glass. Very dark pour that foamed up a bit but quickly faded into a thin ring.
Aromas of bread, malt, toast, leather, soy, coffee. Taste is very bready at first followed by coffee, malt and cocoa. Slightly bitter and salty but pleasant.
A bit thinner than some porters that Ive had. Medium to light body, texture is thin, creamy. Fairly active soft carbonation. Lingering finish...soy and coffee.
All in all quite good but just doesnt strike me as a true porter.

Poured from bomber into tulip glass. (First had this on tap at Sarduccis in Montpelier Vermont.)
Dark black pour with 2 fingers of thick tan head. Hints of ruby red when held to the light. Aromas of malt, chocolate, coffee, rubbing alcohol, toast, soy.
Medium body, creamy texture. Nicely carbonated, fairly lively for a stout.
I would recommend letting this warm before pouring/drinking. Flavors intensify and deepen with a bit of the chill off.
I think I enjoyed this more on tap, but still really good from the bottle. That being said, I got a bottle of this to cellar. Looking forward to seeing how it improves.

Poured from can into tulip glass. Dark bubbly pour with a two finger tan foamy head. Plenty of lacing here. Glass is black with hints of ruby when held to light. Aroma is caramel, malt, black cherry, earthy. Pleasantly sweet taste and finish. Many have said cloyingly sweet but I dont find that at all. Body is fairly light, creamy texture. Carbonation is fizzy but quickly dissipates. My first of this style and I can see myself coming back to this.

Poured from bottle into Crate and Barrel craft beer glass. Hazy amber orange with big fluffy off white head. LOTS of lacing. Big hoppy pine citrus aroma. Taste is sweet and juicy with plenty of hop and malt. Finish is long lingering bitter grapefruit. Very easy to drink. So smooth for a 7+ ABV. Plenty of carbonation. One of my favorite IPAs to date.

Poured from bottle into pint glass. Dark pour with a thin tan head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, nuts, toast, roasty, alcohol, soy sauce, smoke, vanilla, raisin. Full creamy thick body. Carbonation is pretty lively, more than I expected for a stout but nice. Heavy malt flavor, coffee, walnut, molasses, with a long bitter finish. Another great brew from Bells.

Poured from can into shaker glass. Deep dark pour with long lasting tan foamy head. Aroma is hops, malt, roasty. Taste is a nice balace of sweet and bitter. Medium to full body, thick creamy texture. Very nice lively carbonation. Nice slightly dry malty finish. If I had not known this was a black IPA, I would have guessed it was some variety of a stout!

This could become my go-to IPA. Nice aroma of hops, malt and yeast. Taste is much the same. Nicely bitter with plenty of hop flavor and some citrus peel. Lingering bitter finish. Lively carbonation. Decently priced! Another winner from Sierra Nevada.
UPDATED: SEP 23, 2013

Poured from bomber into tulip glass. Beautiful color...like hazy caramel. Good foamy off white head that faded to a thin ring/layer and left some nice lacing.
Aroma is hard to define. Reminds me of some Belgians Ive had. Lots of hops, but also malt. Spice, floral, woody, alcohol, pine. Quite a bit of sweet at first taste but quickly moves to warming alcohol with a long finish. Fairly lively but soft carbonation. Theres a lot going on with this and all of it is very good.

Poured from growler into snifter. Pour is hazy gold with generous foamy white head. Aroma is alcohol, hops, resin, pine, citrus, banana. Taste...wow. First - you would never know this is 8% AVB. Dangerously smooth and crisp. Plenty of hops, citrus rind.  Medium body. Slick yet sticky and creamy texture. Carbonation is soft but noticeable. Very nice long slightly sweet/bitter finish. First had this at a Whole Foods Beer School. May quickly become a favorite!!! Another great local brew!

Poured from bottle into shaker glass. Deep clear amber/red liquid with big fluffy off white head that left lots of lacing. Aroma is hops, resin, spruce, citrus. Medium body, creamy, sticky texture with pretty active carbonation. Taste is pleasant bitter hops, grapefruit, malt. Very nice long grapefruity bitter finish. A very nicely balanced IPA.

Poured from bomber. Nothing all that exciting to look at. Pale clear amber, fairly big fluffy head that quickly faded. 
Aroma...the fun starts. Pineapple, pine, citrus, floral, HOPS, woody, pepper. First sip...so smooth! Big hop presence but not overwhelming. Bigger body than I expected. Full, creamy, thick. Fairly soft carbonation. LONG finish...dry and bitter but so nice. And this is 9.4? Id never guess. 
Like others have said...Ill be keeping my eyes open for every batch of Enjoy By!

Poured from bottle into shaker glass. 
Dark black with just the slightest hint of red when held to light. Big off white head that fades to a creamy layer and leaves lots of lacing. Wonderful aromas of chocolate, coffee, malt, toast with whiffs of rubbing alcohol.
Heavy mouthfeel. Creamy, full thick. Soft carbonation. Nice long roasty aftertaste. A really nice American stout!

Poured from bomber to wheat glass. Nice pour...big fluffy white head. Hazy yellow color with lots of tiny rising bubbles. Made me think of champagne.
Aroma was muddled. Wet grass, fruit, banana, musty. Taste was really disappointing. Yeast, oddly sweet/sour, banana...other flavors I cant identify.
Maybe I got a bad bottle but this is not for me.

Poured into tulip glass. Lovely clear orange copper with a nice fluffy tan head that diminished to a thin layer and ring. Some lacing. Aroma is a lot of rubbing alcohol with orange, hop, caramel. Starts sweet and quickly turns to a long lingering but pleasant bitter. Flavors of orange peel, hops, brown sugar, pine. Medium body, thick creamy texture, lively carbonation. Again...that long nicely bitter finish. My first Laguntis offering and I would certainly have this again.

Poured into tulip glass. Thin foamy white head that quickly faded to a thin white ring around glass.  Gorgeous amber orange butterscotch color.  As to aroma and taste...this is really complex! Aroma is alcohol, orange, banana, butterscotch, hop, fruit, floral. First sip I really noticed the high ABV but it quickly gave way to long lingering sweetness. Full body, thick sticky syrupy mouthfeel but not unpleasantly so. Carbonation is pretty active. Long sweet finish hoppy finish. The bottle says to enjoy as the ale slowly warms. Looking forward to see how aromas and flavors develop as it does.

Dark amber/orange pour with a thin tan head that quickly disappeared leaving just a hint of foam around the edge of liquid. Aroma of apricots, alcohol, yeast. Warming alcohol taste. Apricots, vanilla, cough syrup, butterscotch flavors. Full body, creamy, sticky texture. Carbonation is soft. Finish is long...mostly alcohol with apricots and cough syrup. This is almost brandy-like. Very good. Continue to be impressed with Weyerbach offerings.

Part of the Abita Sampler box. I bought the sampler because my brother loves the Abita Purple Haze and I thought Id give it a try along with some other Abita offerings.

This stuff is BAD. Watery, tasteless at first but with a very strong unpleasant aftertaste. Bad eggs? Hard to describe but definitely awful. Not worth doing a full review. Just terrible stuff... 

Kind of nervous to try the others now.

On tap at 1808 Bistro in Delaware, Ohio. Poured into snifter.
I thought this would go nicely with dessert (beignets) and what a good choice!
Looked so very nice in snifter glass, deep red/amber with thin white head.
Aromas of malt, cherry, vanilla, wood, and brown sugar. Taste was much the same. Lots of sweet here but not cloyingly so. Mouthfeel was full and creamy.
Not something I would drink by the bottle or even all that often, but a small snifter with dessert or after dinner, Id have this again.

Poured from bottle into Imperial Pint glass. Purchased at Whole Foods. First...what a great deal on this...6.99 for a 750ml bottle. Second, I had read that you should let this warm a bit before drinking and that is sound advice. A lot of alcohol warmth here but not overpowering boozy taste. Very complex. Coffee, toast, chocolate, raisins, licorice, smoke, vanilla, and dark fruits. Aroma is much the same. Mouthfeel is heavy, syrupy, thick and oily. Good amount of carbonation without being too much. Finish is long, somewhat astringent, but pleasant. One of the best stouts Ive had to date. Perfect for a nice cool evening. Look forward to having this again!

Recommended by Paul the beer guy at Whole Foods Dublin. First of all, love the bottle. Poured into pint glass. Dark dark pour with minimal tan head. Deep ruby when held to light but mostly just black. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, sugar, raisins, malt, molasses, smoke, and licorice. Many of the same tastes. The label says rich and complex and they are spot on. Mouthfeel is full, thick, creamy. Soft carbonation. One of the best porters Ive had to date. So glad for the recommendation!

Poured from bottle to glass. Appearance is light clear amber with plenty of thick white foam. Lots of tiny fizzy bubbles rising in glass. Plenty of lacing. Aroma is grass, floral, citrus, herb, vanilla. Light body. Some hops, sweet, crisp. Watery finish. Part of a build your own sampler. Doubt Id buy it again.

Part of the Victory Sample box. Poured from bottle into footed pilsner. Pale clear yellow pour with pillowy white head. Plenty of fizzy bubbles. Taste is light, crisp, just a bit of bitterness. Nice hop presence to make this so much more interesting and better than your macro pils.
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2013

Ive had this twice now, once on tap and tonight poured from bottle.  So very good!  Nice black pour with one inch tan head, lots of lacing as its consumed.  Aromas of malt, coffee, vanilla, cocoa.  Same flavors with a touch of brown sugar, molasses and a hint of soy.  Soft carbonation and a full creamy palate.  Great beer from great state!

Poured from bottle.  Part of a sampler.  Dark brown/black with little head and bubbles.  Aroma of caramel, vanilla, chocolate, malts, soy, alcohol.  Good sweet/bitter mix with hints of salty.  More carbonation than I expected based on pour and lack of head.  Body is a bit thin for a porter but a nice offering.  And I love the name!

Part of the Sam Adams Hop Tour 2013. 
Straight from bottle.  Really taste the apricot/peach in this...very pleasant. Would definitely buy a 6pack of this for a summer day or cookout.

Poured from bottle.  Dark amber/orange/red color.  Slightly off white head that faded quickly but lots of lacing all the way down.  Malt, yeast, bread, hop, alcohol aromas.  Taste is nice balance of sweet, bitter and salt (soy).  Medium body, somewhat creamy texture.  Lively carbonation.  My first Great Lakes offering.  Really nice.

Poured from bottle.  Hazy pale orange appearance.  Aroma of hops and citrus.  Hoppy flavor with hints of orange, resin, caramel.  Medium body, soft but lively carbonation.  Long pleasantly bitter finish.  Happy to find such a good local brew!

Nitro tap at World of Beer Easton Mall, Columbus Ohio.  Black/brown pour with beautiful bubble cascade.  Thin tan head.  Full thick mouthfeel.  Sweet, smooth chocolate malty taste.  One of the best stouts Ive had to date.
